appealing for volunteers to train as millers in Yorkshire\u2019s oldest working windmill. \n \nThe Holgate Windmill Preservation Society is looking to increase its group of around 30 active members to help with milling flour for customers in the York area. \n \nThe five-sailed windmill in York was reopened in 2012 after a £500,000 refurbishment, which saw the 18th century, Grade II-listed building restored to working order. \n \nThe mill currently has three trained millers who work one day a week to produce 50kg of flour, which is sold to local restaurants, farm shops and individual customers, with proceeds used for the upkeep of the mill. \n \nSteve Potts, chairman of the society and one of the trained millers, said he believes they could produce 10 times the amount of flour with extra millers and an extra day of milling each week. \n \nHe said anyone interested in learning the skills of one of the oldest professions in the world could be trained in a couple of months. \n \nMr Potts said: \u201cIt\u2019s not a reading skill, it\u2019s a doing and learning by experience skill. We used some of our grant money for a miller to come along and give us on-the-job training. \n \n\u201cPart of it is to come along so we can pass on our skills. It\u2019s about keeping the skills alive.\u201d \n \nHe added: \u201cWe can do 50kg of flour per week but we could do 10 times that if we had the manpower. \n \n\u201cWe started off reasonably gradually because we\u2019re a volunteer group and it\u2019s supposed to be fun but we are trying to make more money out of the milling.\u201d \n \nVolunteers would learn how to work the mill\u2019s sails and motors and how to process the flour. \n \nMr Potts said: \u201cIt\u2019s quite skilled, there\u2019s an element of responsibility. It\u2019s a big powerful machine that could run away with you quite easily.\u201d \n \nVolunteers are also needed to attend the mill\u2019s open days to tell visitors about the history of the building. \n \nAnyone interested in volunteering at Holgate Windmill should contact Mr Potts at chair@holgatewindmill.org","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[],"title":"Trainees with true grist sought for working windmill","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Europe","subregion":"Northern Europe","county":"Dundee","zipCode":"DD1","state":"Scotland","countryCode":"GB","zipArea":"Dundee City","country":"United Kingdom"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Tayside and Fife Courier","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169661741","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"22"},"name":"Tayside and Fife Courier","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Geographic","Local","Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.thecourier.co.uk"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695199272129","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:50:20Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}
{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:50:20Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395970816","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"LEGISLATIVE BODIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"ENVIRONMENTAL DEPARTMENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"US REPUBLICAN PARTY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"US FEDERAL GOVERNMENT","domains":["SUB"],"score":"88"},{"name":"POLITICAL PARTIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"COAL INDUSTRY","domains":["IND"],"score":"56"},{"name":"ENVIRONMENTAL LAW","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"NATIONAL PARKS","domains":["IND"],"score":"71"},{"name":"COAL FIRED PLANTS","domains":["IND"],"score":"70"},{"name":"ENVIRONMENTALISM","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"US STATE GOVERNMENT","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"PESTICIDES","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"DEREGULATION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"87"},{"name":"CLIMATOLOGY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"67"},{"name":"ENVIRONMENT & NATURAL RESOURCES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"LIBERALISM","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"EXECUTIVE ORDERS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"ENERGY & UTILITY POLICY","domains":["IND"],"score":"90"},{"name":"DELAYS & POSTPONEMENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"72"},{"name":"ENERGY & UTILITY DEREGULATION","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"75"},{"name":"EARTH & ATMOSPHERIC SCIENCE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"67"},{"name":"LOBBYING","domains":["SUB"],"score":"76"},{"name":"CONSERVATION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"CANALS & WATERWAYS","domains":["IND"],"score":"76"},{"name":"UNITED STATES","domains":["GEO"],"score":"94"}],"wordCount":"1858","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395970816&p=2kx&v=1&x=vSdMCGEJK00BCCCdGoC_iA","id":"29395970816","content":"Out of all of President Trump\u2019s cabinet nominees, Scott Pruitt  has probably received more heat from the Left and the environmentalist movement than anybody else. From the moment the former Oklahoma attorney general\u2019s name was floated, liberal doomsayers have been putting out warnings of an impending end to environmental protection laws. \n \nBased on the current tone of the mainstream media and the \u201cresistance\u201d movement, you would think the government was about to start mandating coal plants in national parks. As usual, the reality is not what they make it out to be. What Scott Pruitt will really be bringing to the EPA is a badly-needed refocusing on executing this country\u2019s laws instead of making up its own. As EPA administrator, Pruitt will be reining in an agency that has taken off in pursuit of its own agenda with hardly any oversight by elected lawmakers. Under questioning by the Senate last week, he hammered home how the agency has overreached by essentially making its own laws: \u201cEPA is an administrative agency,\u201d as he put it, \u201cnot a legislative body.\u201d \n  \nThose answers are in line with the president\u2019s \u201c America First Energy Plan ,\u201d which emphasizes deregulation, energy independence, and efforts to \u201crefocus the EPA on its essential mission of protecting our air and water.\u201d They also speak directly to a respect for the Constitutional separation of federal and state powers that has been missing from Washington for years. To quote the transition team, one of the items on the presidential agenda is to \u201cissue an executive order barring EPA from overruling federal/state regulatory/permit decisions unless in clear violation of established law.\u201d \n \nTo be fair to liberals and the climate lobby, it\u2019s easy to understand why they\u2019ve gone apoplectic. When the Left couldn\u2019t force an environmentalist agenda on a Republican Congress, these groups focused instead on Obama\u2019s executive branch and essentially created \u201cactivist agencies\u201d in the same way they fostered activist judges. Climate science has been the most obvious battleground, but agriculture has been just as directly affected. The American farm industry has been feeling the EPA breathing down its neck for the past eight years. It isn\u2019t just the \u201c Waters of the United States \u201d rule, a federal power grab disguised as a technical document that defines which waterways fall under the jurisdiction of the EPA. Farmers have also been left hanging for months over of the agency\u2019s recent atrazine and glyphosate reviews, which have been criticized for delays and for allowing interference by activists. \n \nThe glyphosate review is a textbook example of why an executive agency shouldn\u2019t be in the legislative business. Last September, the EPA finally announced preliminary findings on the widely-used pesticide following a years-long evaluation process. In what came as no surprise, the agency concurred with almost every other scientific body (both the U.S. and Europe) in finding that glyphosate does not pose a realistic cancer risk to humans -- a relief for thousands of farmers who had been awaiting the review panel\u2019s consensus. So why did this review take so long? Because left-wing activists, using an outlier result from the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) in France, tried to derail the review process. \n \nThe process became so chaotic that Jason Chaffetz had to launch an investigation calling for answers on why U.S. taxpayer dollars are going to IARC and whether EPA employees might have been colluding with scientists in France to undermine the review being carried out here in America. There are also demands for reforming how IARC\u2019s review process works, since this is just one of several controversies the agency has touched off over the past few years. The Obama administration didn\u2019t seem too bothered by this agency capture on the part of militant environmentalists, but there is no way subterfuge like this will be allowed to continue now that Trump is in office. Instead, the agency will take a markedly more streamlined approach to regulation; Pruitt is set to preside over a shift in power to the states. As Oklahoma attorney general, he had a firm record of support for federalism, pushing back against federal regulations that encroach on state authorities. \n \nThis is, of course, anathema to Democrats, who look down their noses at the states and insist that all rules and regulations emanate from Washington. All of this begs an important question, though: instead of endlessly complaining about Pruitt and limiting the powers of the federal government, why don\u2019t they try to learn from him? Federal agencies respecting constitutional boundaries doesn\u2019t preclude the blue states from enacting whatever onerous environmental regulations they want. In fact, Pruitt\u2019s approach offers a silver lining: without dictates from the feds, left-wing lawmakers in New York and California can implement as many regulations as they please. \n \nEven before Trump\u2019s election, many states and cities were going wild enacting far stricter laws than those required by federal thresholds. In California, people like Jerry Brown now say they plan to bypass Washington and work directly with other nations and states to protect and fortify their laws. States\u2019 attorneys are also tearing a leaf out of Pruitt\u2019s playbook, attacking what they see as federal crimes in the courtroom. California\u2019s Xavier Becerra has already promised to fight the Trump administration on issues ranging from immigration to climate change. \n \nMore power to them. Instead of undercutting popular sovereignty by working through unelected agencies, Becerra and the rest of his party can see whether their arguments and the impositions they want to put on American business can stand up to constitutional scrutiny. Elected lawmakers, and not a semi-autonomous government agency, should be making the rules. \n  \nOut of all of President Trump\u2019s cabinet nominees, Scott Pruitt  has probably received more heat from the Left and the environmentalist movement than anybody else. From the moment the former Oklahoma attorney general\u2019s name was floated, liberal doomsayers have been putting out warnings of an impending end to environmental protection laws. \n \nBased on the current tone of the mainstream media and the \u201cresistance\u201d movement, you would think the government was about to start mandating coal plants in national parks. As usual, the reality is not what they make it out to be. What Scott Pruitt will really be bringing to the EPA is a badly-needed refocusing on executing this country\u2019s laws instead of making up its own. As EPA administrator, Pruitt will be reining in an agency that has taken off in pursuit of its own agenda with hardly any oversight by elected lawmakers. Under questioning by the Senate last week, he hammered home how the agency has overreached by essentially making its own laws: \u201cEPA is an administrative agency,\u201d as he put it, \u201cnot a legislative body.\u201d \n \nThose answers are in line with the president\u2019s \u201c America First Energy Plan ,\u201d which emphasizes deregulation, energy independence, and efforts to \u201crefocus the EPA on its essential mission of protecting our air and water.\u201d They also speak directly to a respect for the Constitutional separation of federal and state powers that has been missing from Washington for years. To quote the transition team, one of the items on the presidential agenda is to \u201cissue an executive order barring EPA from overruling federal/state regulatory/permit decisions unless in clear violation of established law.\u201d \n \nTo be fair to liberals and the climate lobby, it\u2019s easy to understand why they\u2019ve gone apoplectic. When the Left couldn\u2019t force an environmentalist agenda on a Republican Congress, these groups focused instead on Obama\u2019s executive branch and essentially created \u201cactivist agencies\u201d in the same way they fostered activist judges. Climate science has been the most obvious battleground, but agriculture has been just as directly affected. The American farm industry has been feeling the EPA breathing down its neck for the past eight years. It isn\u2019t just the \u201c Waters of the United States \u201d rule, a federal power grab disguised as a technical document that defines which waterways fall under the jurisdiction of the EPA. Farmers have also been left hanging for months over of the agency\u2019s recent atrazine and glyphosate reviews, which have been criticized for delays and for allowing interference by activists. \n \nThe glyphosate review is a textbook example of why an executive agency shouldn\u2019t be in the legislative business. Last September, the EPA finally announced preliminary findings on the widely-used pesticide following a years-long evaluation process. In what came as no surprise, the agency concurred with almost every other scientific body (both the U.S. and Europe) in finding that glyphosate does not pose a realistic cancer risk to humans -- a relief for thousands of farmers who had been awaiting the review panel\u2019s consensus. So why did this review take so long? Because left-wing activists, using an outlier result from the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) in France, tried to derail the review process. \n \nThe process became so chaotic that Jason Chaffetz had to launch an investigation calling for answers on why U.S. taxpayer dollars are going to IARC and whether EPA employees might have been colluding with scientists in France to undermine the review being carried out here in America. There are also demands for reforming how IARC\u2019s review process works, since this is just one of several controversies the agency has touched off over the past few years. The Obama administration didn\u2019t seem too bothered by this agency capture on the part of militant environmentalists, but there is no way subterfuge like this will be allowed to continue now that Trump is in office. Instead, the agency will take a markedly more streamlined approach to regulation; Pruitt is set to preside over a shift in power to the states. As Oklahoma attorney general, he had a firm record of support for federalism, pushing back against federal regulations that encroach on state authorities. \n \nThis is, of course, anathema to Democrats, who look down their noses at the states and insist that all rules and regulations emanate from Washington. All of this begs an important question, though: instead of endlessly complaining about Pruitt and limiting the powers of the federal government, why don\u2019t they try to learn from him? Federal agencies respecting constitutional boundaries doesn\u2019t preclude the blue states from enacting whatever onerous environmental regulations they want. In fact, Pruitt\u2019s approach offers a silver lining: without dictates from the feds, left-wing lawmakers in New York and California can implement as many regulations as they please. \n \nEven before Trump\u2019s election, many states and cities were going wild enacting far stricter laws than those required by federal thresholds. In California, people like Jerry Brown now say they plan to bypass Washington and work directly with other nations and states to protect and fortify their laws. States\u2019 attorneys are also tearing a leaf out of Pruitt\u2019s playbook, attacking what they see as federal crimes in the courtroom. California\u2019s Xavier Becerra has already promised to fight the Trump administration on issues ranging from immigration to climate change. \n \nMore power to them. Instead of undercutting popular sovereignty by working through unelected agencies, Becerra and the rest of his party can see whether their arguments and the impositions they want to put on American business can stand up to constitutional scrutiny. Elected lawmakers, and not a semi-autonomous government agency, should be making the rules.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"France news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"US news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Politics latest","group":"Society"},{"name":"Regulatory news","group":"Business"}],"title":"The Left\u2019s Misplaced Panic over the EPA","source":{"category":"Consumer","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","countryCode":"US","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"American Thinker","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169801596","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"1400"},"name":"American Thinker","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["News","Standard"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.americanthinker.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":["http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2017/jan/10/donald-trump-epa-pick-scott-pruit-decried-by-envir/","http://www.wsj.com/articles/scott-pruitt-is-chief-target-of-opposition-to-trumps-environmental-policy-plan-1484604960","http://motherboard.vice.com/en_uk/read/scott-pruitt-is-an-enemy-of-environmental-protection","http://www.wsj.com/articles/scott-pruitt-donald-trumps-pick-for-epa-chief-plans-to-emphasize-disagreements-with-obama-1484735405","https://www.whitehouse.gov/america-first-energy","https://www.axios.com/axios-am-2207230091.html","http://www.politico.com/story/2015/05/epa-waterways-wetlands-rule-118319","http://www.agweb.com/article/pruitts-epa-confirmation-hearing-set-for-jan-18-naa-ben-potter/","http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-epa-glyphosate-idUSKCN11M28X","https://morningconsult.com/alert/american-chemistry-council-says-chaffetz-right-question-study-glyphosate/","http://campaignforaccuracyinpublichealthresearch.com/","https://www.bna.com/scott-pruitt-tip-n73014449932/","https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/30/opinion/cities-and-states-lead-on-climate-change.html","http://www.politico.com/states/california/story/2017/01/jerry-"],"sequenceId":"695199272769","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:50:20Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}
{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:50:20Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395970823","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"RELIGION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"69"},{"name":"IMMIGRATION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"85"},{"name":"GLOBAL WARMING","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"69"},{"name":"RACISM & XENOPHOBIA","domains":["SUB"],"score":"85"},{"name":"RACE & ETHNICITY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"85"},{"name":"EDITORIALS & OPINIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"IMMIGRATION LAW","domains":["SUB"],"score":"61"},{"name":"EARTH","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"}],"wordCount":"1088","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395970823&p=2kx&v=1&x=DxRolRgD0tT5TQNHq308tg","id":"29395970823","content":"My wife parroted the comment that secondhand smoke is worse for you than firsthand smoke.  I was struck by the obvious insanity of the statement \u2013 and more importantly, the intellectual laziness of subscribing to it.  Now, it is not entirely impossible that 100% of a toxin is less harmful than 5% of a toxin \u2013 perhaps air dilution multiplies the toxicity \u2013 but to readily accept that assertion is simply intellectual laziness.  It would take some really conclusive evidence to believe such a claim, and that evidence does not exist. \n \nAnother good example of intellectual laziness is the global warming hypothesis.  If all the molecules in the atmosphere were lined up between N.Y. and L.A., with CO2 at the front of the line, you would run out of CO2 before your plane got off the runway.  It is called a trace gas because 4 parts in 10,000 is a pretty small fraction.  For CO2 to have the impact claimed, it would have to qualify as a supernatural atom.  Add to that the facts that CO2 represents only maybe 1% of the global heat retention caused by water and that anthropogenic CO2 is a small fraction of global CO2 production, and it is clear that the anthropogenic CO2 \"hypothesis\" is simply farcical. \n  \nThen there is the issue of Islam. Any belief system that asserts that it is necessary to chop a woman's head off if she goes to the market without her husband is not a legitimate philosophy; it is abject insanity.  And for so many to tell themselves that it is valid because it is a \"religion\" is one of the most offensive examples of intellectual laziness.  Slavery has been around since time immemorial, and it never has been and never will be part of a legitimate philosophy. \n \nAnd of course there is the immigration issue.  Every nation on Earth has immigration limits.  When 10% of your population is illegal, it is not immigration; it is invasion.  When you allow yourself to conflate reasonable immigration control with racism, you are being intellectually lazy.  And when you slander with wails of racism those who aren't intellectually lazy, who admit that a country, no matter how wealthy, can't absorb unlimited numbers of the desperately poor without inflicting hardship on the native population, you are guilty of not only intellectual laziness, but also character assassination. \n \nThe most important example of intellectual laziness is the claim that I can't say something that offends you, but you can insult me, offend me, and stone me to death for disagreeing with you.  Telling yourself you can discount other people's opinions and don't have to debate them because you have convinced yourself of your own moral superiority is the pinnacle of intellectual laziness. \n \nBefore the election, a colleague said that it didn't matter, as they were all the same.  In their defense, he would have been correct for nearly every election in my lifetime.  But this time, the differences could not have been more extreme, and to tell oneself that the candidates were the same is, again, a shameful example of intellectual laziness. \n \nTo inherit one of the richest, fairest, and best run countries in the history of the world and then to allow it to be Venezuela-ized is not just intellectually lazy; it is morally lazy, or worse. \n  \nMy wife parroted the comment that secondhand smoke is worse for you than firsthand smoke.  I was struck by the obvious insanity of the statement \u2013 and more importantly, the intellectual laziness of subscribing to it.  Now, it is not entirely impossible that 100% of a toxin is less harmful than 5% of a toxin \u2013 perhaps air dilution multiplies the toxicity \u2013 but to readily accept that assertion is simply intellectual laziness.  It would take some really conclusive evidence to believe such a claim, and that evidence does not exist. \n \nAnother good example of intellectual laziness is the global warming hypothesis.  If all the molecules in the atmosphere were lined up between N.Y. and L.A., with CO2 at the front of the line, you would run out of CO2 before your plane got off the runway.  It is called a trace gas because 4 parts in 10,000 is a pretty small fraction.  For CO2 to have the impact claimed, it would have to qualify as a supernatural atom.  Add to that the facts that CO2 represents only maybe 1% of the global heat retention caused by water and that anthropogenic CO2 is a small fraction of global CO2 production, and it is clear that the anthropogenic CO2 \"hypothesis\" is simply farcical. \n \nThen there is the issue of Islam. Any belief system that asserts that it is necessary to chop a woman's head off if she goes to the market without her husband is not a legitimate philosophy; it is abject insanity.  And for so many to tell themselves that it is valid because it is a \"religion\" is one of the most offensive examples of intellectual laziness.  Slavery has been around since time immemorial, and it never has been and never will be part of a legitimate philosophy. \n \nAnd of course there is the immigration issue.  Every nation on Earth has immigration limits.  When 10% of your population is illegal, it is not immigration; it is invasion.  When you allow yourself to conflate reasonable immigration control with racism, you are being intellectually lazy.  And when you slander with wails of racism those who aren't intellectually lazy, who admit that a country, no matter how wealthy, can't absorb unlimited numbers of the desperately poor without inflicting hardship on the native population, you are guilty of not only intellectual laziness, but also character assassination. \n \nThe most important example of intellectual laziness is the claim that I can't say something that offends you, but you can insult me, offend me, and stone me to death for disagreeing with you.  Telling yourself you can discount other people's opinions and don't have to debate them because you have convinced yourself of your own moral superiority is the pinnacle of intellectual laziness. \n \nBefore the election, a colleague said that it didn't matter, as they were all the same.  In their defense, he would have been correct for nearly every election in my lifetime.  But this time, the differences could not have been more extreme, and to tell oneself that the candidates were the same is, again, a shameful example of intellectual laziness. \n \nTo inherit one of the richest, fairest, and best run countries in the history of the world and then to allow it to be Venezuela-ized is not just intellectually lazy; it is morally lazy, or worse.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[],"title":"A few examples of intellectual laziness","source":{"category":"Consumer","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","countryCode":"US","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"American Thinker","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169801596","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"1400"},"name":"American Thinker","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["News","Standard"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.americanthinker.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695199272962","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:50:20Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}
{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:50:21Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395970843","companies":[{"symbol":"PRSXY","primary":true,"name":"Press Corp Ltd","contentCount":12,"exchange":"PINX","titleCount":0,"isin":"US74111E2090"},{"symbol":"PESA","primary":true,"name":"Press Corp Ltd","contentCount":12,"exchange":"LON","titleCount":0,"isin":"US74111E2090"},{"symbol":"PESD","primary":true,"name":"Press Corp Ltd","contentCount":12,"exchange":"LON","titleCount":0,"isin":"US74111E1001"},{"symbol":"3962","primary":false,"name":"CHANGE Inc","contentCount":2,"exchange":"TKS","titleCount":0,"isin":"JP3507750002"}],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"PRESS CONFERENCES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"NEWS REPORTING","domains":["SUB","IND"],"score":"90"},{"name":"UNITED STATES","domains":["GEO"],"score":"93"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; FLORIDA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"MIAMI, FL, USA; UNITED STATES; FLORIDA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"}],"wordCount":"2188","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395970843&p=2kx&v=1&x=G0idhERR_bNw-dG9snEqLQ","id":"29395970843","content":"As Miami-Dade Mayor proved by abandoning his city\u2019s long-standing status as a Sanctuary City demonstrates, President Trump is a broom that is sweeping clean. He\u2019s dramatically changing how government is \u201csupposed\" to work, focusing instead on making government work better for all Americans.  \n \nAfter what some considered a \u201cfalse start,\u201d Press Secretary Sean Spicer has emulated the President, imposing new procedures on a reluctant, self-focused press corps.  Kudos.  \n  \nThis transformation began when Spicer \u2013 abandoning tradition \u2013 began his very first press Q&A by calling on less well-known reporters, instead of deferring to favored, \u201cfront row\u201d media.   He then doubled down by stripping the senior-most press corps member\u2019s \u201cright\u201d to close each press briefing.  Both of those \u201cpress perks\u201d gave the White House press corps real power over these briefings. \n \nThat was in fact a great start, but even more is needed to take back control of press briefings. \n \nSpicer is the President\u2019s surrogate.  He needs to abandon previous press secretaries\u2019 behavior \u2013 many were just far too deferential to the press. That deference closed an open conduit between their Presidents and the American people. So Spicer should keep challenging the press corps\u2019 prerogatives, resetting the ground rules of the game.  \n \nChallenge Reporters\u2019 Self-Imposed Privileges:  \n \nReporters set their own agendas, no longer following the Administration\u2019s lead. Right out of the box, Spicer successfully challenged a couple of the most petty \u201cpress perks.\u201d   \n \nOther press perks remain in force.  They have a common denominator \u2013 they feed the reporters\u2019 sense of self-importance without improving public dialogue.  It\u2019s up to Spicer to follow President Trump\u2019s \u201cdisruptive\u201d example.  Perks that need to change include: \n \nMove the Briefing Room to the OEOB:   \n \nThis was mooted by the transition team, but has not yet been adopted. Because of the media\u2019s obsession with Trump, the standing-room-only briefing room now has far more reporters than seats, with many other second-tier White House reporters completely shut out.  This crowding justifies moving the briefing room to the Old Executive Office Building \u2013 the OEOB.  The press pool doesn\u2019t like this idea \u2013 but their concerns are based on ego-driven privilege.  Americans outside the Beltway would be hard-pressed to care less about where the briefings are held \u2013 but they will respond favorably to an honest effort to open the briefings to as many reporters as want to participate. \n \nEliminate Multiple Questions:  \n \nWhile Spicer has made a good-faith effort to limit follow-on questions, especially when reporters choose to ignore his initial answer and ask the same question again \u2013 and again \u2013 he needs to go further, if only because of the frequent efforts by reporters to keep pushing for more than one question are one of the most destructive elements of press perks. \n \nTo accomplish this, Spicer should tell reporters to, \u201c look around the room \u2013 there are far more of you here  who want to ask questions  than we have time for.  So, going forward \u2013 and out of respect to both you and your colleagues \u2013 I ask that each of you limit yourself to one question .\u201d  \n \nWhen this doesn\u2019t work \u2013 and it won\u2019t: Reporters will keep trying to ask multiple questions \u2013 Spicer should remind them of his initial request, then tell them: \u201c since trying to motivate you out of professional courtesy isn\u2019t working, going forward, each reporter gets one question \u2013 and, if appropriate, one follow-up question on the same topic.  Again, out of fairness, I will no longer entertain or respond to multiple questions asked by single reporters .\u201d  \n \nEgo-driven reporters won\u2019t take this well, but the American people \u2013 who care nothing about reporters and their perks \u2013 will respond favorably to Spicer\u2019s essential fairness. \n \nDeal with Repetitive Questions:  \n \nRelated to reporters\u2019 habit of asking a string of questions on often varied topics is the press corps\u2019 \u201crepetitive question\u201d habit.  When several reporters ask a question that\u2019s already been asked \u2013 and answered \u2013 they hope that Spicer will cave in. They assume that, on the fourth repetition, the press secretary will finally answer what he\u2019d refused to answer on the first three tries.  Repeating the same question has often lead to a media feeding frenzy, which helps to explain this habitual media behavior.  \n \nHowever, this can be handled easily, especially once Spicer has already asked reporters to limit themselves to one question.  When a reporter repeats an already-answered question, Spicer should say, in effect, \u201c you have just one question today, and since I\u2019ve already answered your question, and since the facts haven\u2019t changed in the last five minutes, are you really sure you want to waste your one question by asking me this same question, and getting my same answer ?\u201d  \n \nThis approach will deliver an immediate benefit.  Smart reporters will quickly learn to reconsider wasting their one question.  Doing so will limit the risk of elevating a question into an issue, or even into a feeding frenzy. \n \nChallenge Reporters\u2019 Underlying Assumptions:  \n \nSpicer should never accept a reporter\u2019s question\u2019s underlying assumption, especially if that assumption reflects hostility toward the President or his agenda. An example of this kind of assumption came up the other day, when a reporter cited the NAACP\u2019s chieftain\u2019s inaccurate charge that President Trump was \u2013 by his choice of meetings \u2013 stereotyping black Americans.  Instead of just pointing out exceptions to this blatantly false assumption \u2013 which Spicer did, effectively \u2013 he should push back on the underlying assumption itself.    \n \nTo do this, first challenge the assumption directly.  Then provide a single specific example which refutes the assumption. In that kind of case, Spicer could have said, \u201c We reject your question\u2019s underlying assumption. The President has not limited his meetings with prominent black Americans to entertainers and athletes.  For instance, the President met with Dr. Martin Luther King Junior\u2019s eldest son, himself a prominent civil rights leader, and did so on Martin Luther King Jr. Day .\u201d \n \nThis would have demolished both the question and the underlying attack hidden within the question.  \n \nConclusion:   \n \nThe result of following these suggestions would return more control to the Administration, without denying reporters the right to ask a specific question.  This will create press briefings that generate more news, and more accurate information for the public by limiting the press corps\u2019 ability to control the process, regardless of its inefficiency. \n \nAbout Ned Barnett:   Barnett has managed \u2013 at a state level \u2013 media and strategy in three Presidential elections, beginning with Gerald Ford\u2019s South Carolina campaign.  He has also managed dozens of political and issues-oriented campaigns. In addition to having trained many political and business clients to more effectively meet the media, he has taught professional communications at several universities and has written more than a dozen published books on effective press relations. \n  \nAs Miami-Dade Mayor proved by abandoning his city\u2019s long-standing status as a Sanctuary City demonstrates, President Trump is a broom that is sweeping clean. He\u2019s dramatically changing how government is \u201csupposed\" to work, focusing instead on making government work better for all Americans.  \n \nAfter what some considered a \u201cfalse start,\u201d Press Secretary Sean Spicer has emulated the President, imposing new procedures on a reluctant, self-focused press corps.  Kudos.  \n \nThis transformation began when Spicer \u2013 abandoning tradition \u2013 began his very first press Q&A by calling on less well-known reporters, instead of deferring to favored, \u201cfront row\u201d media.   He then doubled down by stripping the senior-most press corps member\u2019s \u201cright\u201d to close each press briefing.  Both of those \u201cpress perks\u201d gave the White House press corps real power over these briefings. \n \nThat was in fact a great start, but even more is needed to take back control of press briefings. \n \nSpicer is the President\u2019s surrogate.  He needs to abandon previous press secretaries\u2019 behavior \u2013 many were just far too deferential to the press. That deference closed an open conduit between their Presidents and the American people. So Spicer should keep challenging the press corps\u2019 prerogatives, resetting the ground rules of the game.  \n \nChallenge Reporters\u2019 Self-Imposed Privileges:  \n \nReporters set their own agendas, no longer following the Administration\u2019s lead. Right out of the box, Spicer successfully challenged a couple of the most petty \u201cpress perks.\u201d   \n \nOther press perks remain in force.  They have a common denominator \u2013 they feed the reporters\u2019 sense of self-importance without improving public dialogue.  It\u2019s up to Spicer to follow President Trump\u2019s \u201cdisruptive\u201d example.  Perks that need to change include: \n \nMove the Briefing Room to the OEOB:   \n \nThis was mooted by the transition team, but has not yet been adopted. This crowding justifies moving the briefing room to the Old Executive Office Building \u2013 the OEOB.  The press pool doesn\u2019t like this idea \u2013 but their concerns are based on ego-driven privilege.  Americans outside the Beltway would be hard-pressed to care less about where the briefings are held \u2013 but they will respond favorably to an honest effort to open the briefings to as many reporters as want to participate. \n \nEliminate Multiple Questions:  \n \nWhile Spicer has made a good-faith effort to limit follow-on questions, especially when reporters choose to ignore his initial answer and ask the same question again \u2013 and again \u2013 he needs to go further, if only because of the frequent efforts by reporters to keep pushing for more than one question are one of the most destructive elements of press perks. \n \nTo accomplish this, Spicer should tell reporters to, \u201c look around the room \u2013 there are far more of you here  who want to ask questions  than we have time for.  So, going forward \u2013 and out of respect to both you and your colleagues \u2013 I ask that each of you limit yourself to one question .\u201d  \n \nWhen this doesn\u2019t work \u2013 and it won\u2019t: Reporters will keep trying to ask multiple questions \u2013 Spicer should remind them of his initial request, then tell them: \u201c since trying to motivate you out of professional courtesy isn\u2019t working, going forward, each reporter gets one question \u2013 and, if appropriate, one follow-up question on the same topic.  Again, out of fairness, I will no longer entertain or respond to multiple questions asked by single reporters .\u201d  \n \nEgo-driven reporters won\u2019t take this well, but the American people \u2013 who care nothing about reporters and their perks \u2013 will respond favorably to Spicer\u2019s essential fairness. \n \nDeal with Repetitive Questions:  \n \nRelated to reporters\u2019 habit of asking a string of questions on often varied topics is the press corps\u2019 \u201crepetitive question\u201d habit.  When several reporters ask a question that\u2019s already been asked \u2013 and answered \u2013 they hope that Spicer will cave in. They assume that, on the fourth repetition, the press secretary will finally answer what he\u2019d refused to answer on the first three tries.  Repeating the same question has often lead to a media feeding frenzy, which helps to explain this habitual media behavior.  \n \nHowever, this can be handled easily, especially once Spicer has already asked reporters to limit themselves to one question.  When a reporter repeats an already-answered question, Spicer should say, in effect, \u201c you have just one question today, and since I\u2019ve already answered your question, and since the facts haven\u2019t changed in the last five minutes, are you really sure you want to waste your one question by asking me this same question, and getting my same answer ?\u201d  \n \nThis approach will deliver an immediate benefit.  Smart reporters will quickly learn to reconsider wasting their one question.  Doing so will limit the risk of elevating a question into an issue, or even into a feeding frenzy. \n \nChallenge Reporters\u2019 Underlying Assumptions:  \n \nSpicer should never accept a reporter\u2019s question\u2019s underlying assumption, especially if that assumption reflects hostility toward the President or his agenda. The President has not limited his meetings with prominent black Americans to entertainers and athletes.  For instance, the President met with Dr. Martin Luther King Junior\u2019s eldest son, himself a prominent civil rights leader, and did so on Martin Luther King Jr. Day .\u201d \n \nThis would have demolished both the question and the underlying attack hidden within the question.  \n \nConclusion:   \n \nThe result of following these suggestions would return more control to the Administration, without denying reporters the right to ask a specific question.  This will create press briefings that generate more news, and more accurate information for the public by limiting the press corps\u2019 ability to control the process, regardless of its inefficiency. \n \nAbout Ned Barnett:   Barnett has managed \u2013 at a state level \u2013 media and strategy in three Presidential elections, beginning with Gerald Ford\u2019s South Carolina campaign.  He has also managed dozens of political and issues-oriented campaigns. In addition to having trained many political and business clients to more effectively meet the media, he has taught professional communications at several universities and has written more than a dozen published books on effective press relations.","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[],"title":"More 'Rules' Sean Spicer Can Change for the Press Pool","source":{"category":"Consumer","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","countryCode":"US","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"American Thinker","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"169801596","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"1400"},"name":"American Thinker","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["News","Standard"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.americanthinker.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695199273362","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:50:21Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}
{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:50:22Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395971035","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"STATE DEPARTMENTS & FOREIGN SERVICES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"EMBASSIES & CONSULATES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"TALKS & MEETINGS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"US FEDERAL GOVERNMENT","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"FOREIGN POLICY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"75"},{"name":"ISRAELI-PALESTINIAN CONFLICTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"UNITED NATIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"91"},{"name":"UNITED NATIONS INSTITUTIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"92"},{"name":"PUBLIC POLICY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"75"},{"name":"INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"PEACE PROCESS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"72"},{"name":"AGREEMENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"MILITARY OCCUPATIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"VETO","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"TREATIES & AGREEMENTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"70"},{"name":"PALESTINIAN TERRITORY, OCCUPIED","domains":["GEO"],"score":"93"},{"name":"JERUSALEM, ISRAEL; ISRAEL","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"MIDDLE EAST","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"ISRAEL","domains":["GEO"],"score":"98"},{"name":"UNITED STATES","domains":["GEO"],"score":"94"},{"name":"JOHN KERRY","domains":["PEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"BARACK OBAMA","domains":["PEO"],"score":"79"}],"wordCount":"2144","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395971035&p=2kx&v=1&x=lT_Vey00wpxip0ORKQ1PqQ","id":"29395971035","content":", the United Nations announced the passage of UN Security Council Resolution 2334 , which condemns Israeli settlements east of the 1949 armistice line, that is, in the West Bank and East Jerusalem (including the Old City with its ancient Jewish Quarter). Passage of this resolution was only possible because of the deliberate refusal of the U.S. to exercise the veto power it wields as one of the five permanent members of the Security Council.  Secretary of State John Kerry insisted that in refusing to veto the resolution, the Obama administration was simply conforming to long-standing U.S. policy in favor of the \u201ctwo-state solution\u201d of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, a policy that has also included U.S. condemnation of Israeli settlement building in the West Bank. [1] In fact, however, UNSC Resolution 2334 is a departure from past precedent, both for the Security Council and for the U.S., and one that creates big problems for Israel. Moreover, the Trump administration will probably not be able to reverse this new state of affairs, since the other permanent members of the Security Council would presumably use their veto power to protect Resolution 2334. It is therefore important to understand the impact of this resolution. \n \n For the past half-century, a key point of reference in all discussion surrounding Israeli-Palestinian peace talks has been UN Security Council Resolution 242 , passed on November 22, 1967 in the wake of the June 1967 Arab-Israeli war. This resolution famously called for the \u201cwithdrawal of Israel armed forces from territories occupied in the recent conflict,\u201d but only in the context of a peace agreement that would guarantee the sovereignty and territorial integrity of every state in the area, including Israel. While Resolution 242 emphasizes \u201cthe inadmissibility of the acquisition of territory by war,\u201d the key diplomatic players at the time also stressed that Israel had no clearly defined borders that would exclude territories in the West Bank as unambiguously lying outside of its boundaries. On December 9, 1969, U.S. Secretary of State William Rogers made the point as follows: \n  \n\u201cThe boundaries from which the 1967 war began were established by the 1949 armistice agreements, and have defined the areas of national jurisdiction in the Middle East for twenty years. Those boundaries were armistice lines, not final political borders. The Security Council Resolution [242] neither endorses nor precludes the armistice lines as the definitive political boundaries.\u201d [2] \n \nU.S. Ambassador to the UN Arthur Goldberg made the same point in debate at the UN on November 15, 1967, pointing out that there had never been agreement on permanent borders between Israel and her neighbors after the 1948 war and that the 1949 armistice lines were just that \u2013 provisional lines based on purely military considerations. \u201cThese lines, he said, stood to be revised as a part of the transition to peace.\u201d [3] \n \n                 Moreover, Resolution 242 deliberately refrained from demanding Israeli withdrawal from \u201c the territories\u201d occupied in the Six-Day War, instead calling for withdrawal from \u201cterritories\u201d occupied in that war, without defining the extent of the withdrawal. Abba Eban, the Israeli Foreign Minister at the time, notes that the British government sponsored Resolution 242 and so its interpretation of the text deserves special weight. Key British diplomats went on the record as stating that the withdrawal envisaged by the resolution was not to be from \u201call the territories,\u201d but only from some. [4] More recently, Northwestern University Law School professor Eugene Kontorovich, one of the leading scholars on this topic, has demonstrated that Resolution 242 \u201ccontemplates only a partial Israeli withdrawal.\u201d [5] Kontorovich points out, for example, that over several months of deliberations in the Security Council, British and U.S. diplomats repeatedly rebuffed efforts by Arab-aligned nations to require withdrawal from \u201call\u201d or \u201cthe territories.\u201d [6] \n \n         In short, one cannot reasonably interpret UN Resolution 242 as denying Israel a right to retain and settle any of the territories it occupied in 1967. Yet this is exactly what the Obama administration and Resolution 2334 have now done. Resolution 242, as Abba Eban points out, does not even mention the \u201carmistice lines of 1949\u201d or the \u201clines of June 4, 1967,\u201d let alone describe them as sacrosanct and inviolable international boundaries. [7] In contrast, Resolution 2334 \n Presupposes \u201ca two-State solution based on the 1967 lines.\u201d  \u201c Reaffirms that the establishment by Israel of settlements in the Palestinian territory occupied since 1967, including East Jerusalem , has no legal validity and constitutes a flagrant violation under international law\u2026\u201d [emphasis added]  Demands \u201cthat Israel immediately and completely cease all settlement activities in the occupied Palestinian territory, including East Jerusalem \u2026\u201d [emphasis added]  Presupposes, as the two preceding bullet points show, that all the territory occupied by Israel in 1967 is (or already was) \u201cPalestinian territory.\u201d  Urges \u201can end to the Israeli occupation that began in 1967.\u201d  \nIt is highly significant that resolution 2334 begins with an explicit re-affirmation of resolution 242. In doing so, it imposes a (historically false) reinterpretation on the text of resolution 242. According to this anachronistic re-interpretation, resolution 242 is now seen as calling for Israeli withdrawal from all the territories occupied in 1967 and presupposes the sacrosanctity of the 1949 armistice lines as if they were the agree-upon international frontier between Israel and her neighbors. \n \nThe upshot is that Israel now finds itself in a dramatically weaker bargaining position in any future peace talks with the Palestinians. Consider just one point of contention, the status of the Western Wall plaza and the Jewish Quarter of the Old City of Jerusalem, of inestimable cultural and religious significance to Jews everywhere and both falling to the east of the 1949 armistice line. The UN Security Council is now on record as stating that Israeli occupation of these sites \u201chas no legal validity and constitutes a flagrant violation under international law.\u201d Palestinian negotiators can now use this small patch of earth to extract much bigger concessions from Israel. Imagine a Palestinian negotiating team saying to their Israeli counterparts, \u201cOh, so you want us to give you the Western Wall. Well, how much is it worth to you?\u201d Consider also the fact that Palestinians have consistently stressed that any future land swap in a peace deal must be equal in size and quality. [8] If Israel wishes to swap some part of its pre-1967 territory for the Western Wall, which portion exactly would be \u201cequal in quality\u201d? \n \nJohn Kerry insists that the U.S. abstention was motivated by friendship for Israel, but by weakening Israel as it does, the abstention is more a violation than a fulfillment of the obligations of friendship. \n     \n[2] Quoted in Abba Eban, An Autobiography (New York: Random House, 1977), p. 452. \n   \n[3] Abba Eban An Autobiography , p. 450. \n   \n[4] Abba Eban, An Autobiography , p. 452. \n   \n[6] Kontorovich, \u201cResolution 242 Revisited,\u201d pp. 129-130. \n   \n[7] Abba Eban, An Autobiography , p. 451. \n    \nOn December 23, 2016, the United Nations announced the passage of UN Security Council Resolution 2334 , which condemns Israeli settlements east of the 1949 armistice line, that is, in the West Bank and East Jerusalem (including the Old City with its ancient Jewish Quarter). Passage of this resolution was only possible because of the deliberate refusal of the U.S. to exercise the veto power it wields as one of the five permanent members of the Security Council.  Secretary of State John Kerry insisted that in refusing to veto the resolution, the Obama administration was simply conforming to long-standing U.S. policy in favor of the \u201ctwo-state solution\u201d of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, a policy that has also included U.S. condemnation of Israeli settlement building in the West Bank. [1] In fact, however, UNSC Resolution 2334 is a departure from past precedent, both for the Security Council and for the U.S., and one that creates big problems for Israel. Moreover, the Trump administration will probably not be able to reverse this new state of affairs, since the other permanent members of the Security Council would presumably use their veto power to protect Resolution 2334. It is therefore important to understand the impact of this resolution. \n \n For the past half-century, a key point of reference in all discussion surrounding Israeli-Palestinian peace talks has been UN Security Council Resolution 242 , passed on November 22, 1967 in the wake of the June 1967 Arab-Israeli war. This resolution famously called for the \u201cwithdrawal of Israel armed forces from territories occupied in the recent conflict,\u201d but only in the context of a peace agreement that would guarantee the sovereignty and territorial integrity of every state in the area, including Israel. While Resolution 242 emphasizes \u201cthe inadmissibility of the acquisition of territory by war,\u201d the key diplomatic players at the time also stressed that Israel had no clearly defined borders that would exclude territories in the West Bank as unambiguously lying outside of its boundaries. On December 9, 1969, U.S. Secretary of State William Rogers made the point as follows: \n \n\u201cThe boundaries from which the 1967 war began were established by the 1949 armistice agreements, and have defined the areas of national jurisdiction in the Middle East for twenty years. Those boundaries were armistice lines, not final political borders. The Security Council Resolution [242] neither endorses nor precludes the armistice lines as the definitive political boundaries.\u201d [2] \n \nU.S. Ambassador to the UN Arthur Goldberg made the same point in debate at the UN on November 15, 1967, pointing out that there had never been agreement on permanent borders between Israel and her neighbors after the 1948 war and that the 1949 armistice lines were just that \u2013 provisional lines based on purely military considerations. \u201cThese lines, he said, stood to be revised as a part of the transition to peace.\u201d [3] \n \n                 Moreover, Resolution 242 deliberately refrained from demanding Israeli withdrawal from \u201c the territories\u201d occupied in the Six-Day War, instead calling for withdrawal from \u201cterritories\u201d occupied in that war, without defining the extent of the withdrawal. Abba Eban, the Israeli Foreign Minister at the time, notes that the British government sponsored Resolution 242 and so its interpretation of the text deserves special weight. Key British diplomats went on the record as stating that the withdrawal envisaged by the resolution was not to be from \u201call the territories,\u201d but only from some. [4] More recently, Northwestern University Law School professor Eugene Kontorovich, one of the leading scholars on this topic, has demonstrated that Resolution 242 \u201ccontemplates only a partial Israeli withdrawal.\u201d [5] Kontorovich points out, for example, that over several months of deliberations in the Security Council, British and U.S. diplomats repeatedly rebuffed efforts by Arab-aligned nations to require withdrawal from \u201call\u201d or \u201cthe territories.\u201d [6] \n \n         In short, one cannot reasonably interpret UN Resolution 242 as denying Israel a right to retain and settle any of the territories it occupied in 1967. Yet this is exactly what the Obama administration and Resolution 2334 have now done. Resolution 242, as Abba Eban points out, does not even mention the \u201carmistice lines of 1949\u201d or the \u201clines of June 4, 1967,\u201d let alone describe them as sacrosanct and inviolable international boundaries. [7] In contrast, Resolution 2334 \n Presupposes \u201ca two-State solution based on the 1967 lines.\u201d  \u201c Reaffirms that the establishment by Israel of settlements in the Palestinian territory occupied since 1967, including East Jerusalem , has no legal validity and constitutes a flagrant violation under international law\u2026\u201d [emphasis added]  Demands \u201cthat Israel immediately and completely cease all settlement activities in the occupied Palestinian territory, including East Jerusalem \u2026\u201d [emphasis added]  Presupposes, as the two preceding bullet points show, that all the territory occupied by Israel in 1967 is (or already was) \u201cPalestinian territory.\u201d  Urges \u201can end to the Israeli occupation that began in 1967.\u201d  \nIt is highly significant that resolution 2334 begins with an explicit re-affirmation of resolution 242. In doing so, it imposes a (historically false) reinterpretation on the text of resolution 242. According to this anachronistic re-interpretation, resolution 242 is now seen as calling for Israeli withdrawal from all the territories occupied in 1967 and presupposes the sacrosanctity of the 1949 armistice lines as if they were the agree-upon international frontier between Israel and her neighbors. \n \nThe upshot is that Israel now finds itself in a dramatically weaker bargaining position in any future peace talks with the Palestinians. {"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:45:13Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395971068","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"ELECTIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"PRESS CONFERENCES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"62"},{"name":"POLITICS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"76"},{"name":"EARLY RETIREMENT","domains":["SUB"],"score":"68"},{"name":"FAMILY","domains":["SUB"],"score":"73"},{"name":"INDIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"INDIA; UTTAR PRADESH, INDIA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"90"},{"name":"SONIA GANDHI","domains":["PEO"],"score":"79"}],"wordCount":"1215","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395971068&p=2kx&v=1&x=tmmCmCa_Dp3b2jXdFmBhZw","id":"29395971068","content":"Lucknow, Jan 29: It seems to be the stuff from a Bollywood potboiler. Two unlikely bedfellows join forces to combat a mighty villain. But the Congress party and the Samajwadi Party have two villains\u2013the BJP and the BSP. The opponents are divided but still strong. The SP-Congress alliance may not be the strongest contenders in the upcoming Uttar Pradesh Assembly elections, but they are stronger than what they were as individual units. In Bollywood potboilers, the strange bedfellows win in the end and the villains lose. But in politics, there are no villains\u2013just winners and losers. \n \nWho would have thought a few months ago that Samajwadi Party will force its founder president Mulayam Singh Yadav, a shrewd politician, into an early retirement? But the fate had it in store for him. A family feud that he claimed to be resolving dug his political grave and sent him packing into Samajwadi Party\u2019s \u2018margadarshak mandal\u2019. His son Akhilesh Yadav, who unceremoniously dethroned the veteran politician, scampered into an alliance with the Congress party that had no presence in the state and was electorally doomed. There were growling and whimpering in the Samajwadi party ranks but Akhilesh anyway went ahead with the move\u2013his first enormous political gamble that he played without interference by his small council that he exiled as he assumed power in the party. Akhilesh Yadav finally agreed to a 298-105 seat-sharing formula with the Congress after its matriarch Sonia Gandhi\u2019s timely intervention. And here they are campaigning together in Lucknow\u2013a new king and a reluctant prince. \n \nAkhilesh Yadav and Congress Vice-President Rahul Gandhi hit the campaign trail together for the first time in their political careers. They addressed a press conference together and then showed their solidarity and strength with a road show in the state capital. Posters with the slogan \u2018UP ko yeh saath pasand hai\u2019 having the pictures of both Rahul Gandhi and Akhilesh Yadav with their party symbols have been also released. The \u2018tri-colour\u2019 and \u2018red and green\u2019 colours of both the parties will form the border of the posters. Only that no one knows for sure will UP likes this marriage or not. \n \nAs of now, things look hunky-dory for the new alliance. The two leaders are campaigning together. Talks are that they would soon be addressing rallies together in the state. The two parties were still haggling over some seats in Amethi and Rae Bareli, the parliamentary turf of Congress president Sonia Gandhi and her son Rahul. But that little glitch will be solved in all likelihood. Akhilesh had recently joined a Congress leader in a rally in Lakhimpur Kheri. His sister-in-law Aparna Yadav told a news channel that Priyanka Gandhi Vadra may campaign for her in Lucknow Cantt. It may be possible that Akhilesh\u2019s wife Dimple Yadav\u2014who played a big role in stitching the alliance together\u2014may campaign with Priyanka Gandhi Vadra. The Uttar Pradesh chief minister is confident of at least getting more than 300 seats out of 403. \n \nWhy are they together? \n \n\u201cFor the unity of the country and committed to the idea of secularism, SP and Congress will contest the 2017 polls together. We appeal to the supporters to vote for the candidates of the two parties to take forward the agenda of development started by chief minister Akhilesh Yadav,\u201d Samajwadi Party state president Naresh Uttam had said at a joint press conference with Raj Babbar. \n \nHowever, the real reason is the minority votes. The minorities especially Muslims traditionally vote for both the parties. During negotiations for the alliance, both the parties were squabbling for seats with more minority presence. \n \nThe route of the road show was decided so that it also covered the Muslim-dominated areas besides those which have the concentration of the youth population. Pretty much sums their intention. \n \nTraditionally, Muslim voters have been a big deciding factor in the state. The Muslim voters do not vote for the BJP, so they support either Congress or SP. The Congress-SP alliance intends to keep the vote bank consolidated. \n \nAlso, there are calculations in Akhilesh Yadav\u2019s mind. The party leader is eyeing more than 35 %voteshare to get around 300 seats to retain power. In 2012, SP had got 29.13% votes. The Congress had got 11.65% votes. Together, both the parties can reach the magical figure. \n \n\n \nWhy is this alliance significant even after UP polls? \n \nUttar Pradesh is the biggest state in the country in terms of the Lok Sabha seats. The enormous state has 80 constituencies. In 2014 General Elections, the Bharatiya Janata Party dismantled all the other parties in the state. They had got 71 seats and a whopping vote share 42.30 percent. The party got a landslide victory and went on to form a popular government in Delhi under Prime Minister Narendra Modi. The vote percentage of the BJP in the state compared to 2009 was increased by 24%. It was understood later that a Modi wave had come swept away with votes in the states. The Samajwadi Party and the BSP that were the two largest parties in 2009, were destroyed. \n \nSP had 23 seats in 2009, they were reduced to 5 seats in 2014. BSP had 20 seats in 2009, they couldn\u2019t even open their accounts. The Congress party had 26 seats in 2009, they were reduced to a mere 2 seats in the state. \n \n\n \nThe vote shares of the parties didn\u2019t dip much individually. There was 1.06 points dip in SP\u2019s vote share, whereas BSP got 7.82 points lesser votes than in 2009. The Congress party took the biggest hit with a dip pf 10.75 points. \n \nThe main reason for such a performance by BJP was Narendra Modi alone. The charismatic leader mesmerised the voters with his promise of \u2018ache din\u2019. However, things have changed now. Under his leadership, the party lost two major elections\u2013Delhi and Bihar. The two results clearly showed that he was not invincible. The Modi wave has cooled down and even Prime Minister Narendra Modi is facing flak for his demonetisation move and heavy tax regime. The government is also going to undertake a tectonic shift in India\u2019s taxation\u2013the GST. Economists say that it will be a welcome economic reform, but no one is sure about the political implications of the move as most of the services will get more expensive after its implementation. It has the real potential of backfiring to the Modi government electorally. Without the Modi wave, the Congress and the Samajwadi Party together have a big chance of bouncing back in the 2019 general elections. \n \nThere are 80 seats in Uttar Pradesh. In 2009 general elections, the SP had got 23.26% votes and was the single-largest party in the state with 23 seats in their kitty. The Congress had got 21 seats with a vote share of 18.25%. The BJP could only get 10 seats with a vote share 17.50%. If Akhilesh Yadav and Rahul Gandhi remain together till 2009, they can make a real dent in BJP\u2019s voters base. BJP\u2019s policies at the Centre may have a direct impact in the state. Whereas, people can show their confidence on the refurbished Samajwadi Party under the leadership Akhilesh Yadav, who enjoys a clean and pro-development image. If they contest the 2019 elections together and even repeat their performance in 2009 in the absence of a political wave, they can get a vote share of 35% plus and that is enough to destroy the BJP in the state. A vote share of 40% or more can get them around 50 seats and it can make a major difference nationally. \n \n ","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Vaibhav Tiwari"},"topics":[{"name":"India news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Indian subcontinent news","group":"Regional"}],"title":"If Akhilesh Yadav-Rahul Gandhi get success in UP Assembly polls 2017, it can prove detrimental to Narendra Modi\u2019s plans for 2019","source":{"category":"National","location":{"region":"Asia","subregion":"Southern Asia","countryCode":"IN","country":"India"},"editorialRank":"3","name":"India.com","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"597540856","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"0"},"name":"India.com","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Geographic","National","Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.india.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695199275384","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:45:13Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:50:22Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[{"url":"http://s3.india.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/01/Akhilesh-Rahul.jpg"}],"video":[]}}

Afonso Dhlakama has accused government forces of violating a ceasefire his armed group Renamo had declared following a surge in deadly violence last year. \n\nMozambique's rebel leader Afonso Dhlakama (C) claimed the government was not taking its ceasefire overtures seriously | © AFP/File | GIANLUIGI GUERCIA \n\nDhlakama, who only gives rare interviews by phone from the central Gorongosa mountains where he has been holed-up since October 2015, claimed the government was not taking its ceasefire overtures seriously. \n\nThe army \u201cambushes, kidnaps and detains\u201d rebels and Renamo supporters, he told AFP in an interview on Friday. \n\n\u201cThere have been deaths,\u201d he claimed but gave no details. \n\nOn January 3, Dhlakama announced a two-month ceasefire, extending a week-long truce he had declared in late December \u2014 a move welcomed by Mozambique\u2019s President Filipe Nyusi. \n\nWorsening clashes between the ruling Frelimo party government and rebel group Renamo last year had revived the spectre of Mozambique\u2019s civil war that ended more than 20 years ago. \n\nDhlakama\u2019s Renamo is an armed insurgent group that led a 16-year rebellion and an opposition political party that took up arms again in 2013. \n\nThe death toll in the conflict is unknown but Dhlakama claims that \u201chundreds and hundreds of people have died between the start of 2015 and the end of 2016\u2033. \n\n\u2013 \u2018Trying to kill Dhlakama?\u2019 \u2013 \n\nWhile admitting the army has not staged any offensive against his bush military base for a month, Dhlakama castigated what he described as \u201creconnaissance missions\u201d around the camp where he is hiding. \n\n\u201cWhat are they doing there? Are they still planning to kill Dhlakama?\u201d asked the 64-year-old rebel, who often speaks about himself in the third person. \n\n\u201cAre they trying to find the river where Dhlakama is drinking from to poison it, or the roads we use to plant anti-personnel landmines?\u201d \n\nDhlakama, whose Renamo party is the main opposition in Mozambique, retreated in October 2012 to his hideout in Gorongosa with 800 former guerrillas demanding a greater share of power. \n\nIn 2013 tensions resurfaced with Renamo fighters again taking up arms against Frelimo, accusing the ruling party of enriching itself at the expense of the southern African country. \n\nOn the eve of the October 2014 general elections Renamo and the government signed a ceasefire. \n\nBut Renamo refused to accept the results of the 2014 elections when it was beaten once more at the polls by Frelimo, which has been in power since the former Portuguese colony\u2019s independence 40 years ago \n\n\u2013 \u2018Won\u2019t give up on truce\u2019 \u2013 \n\nDhlakama has accused the army of not only targeting Renamo members but civilians too. \n\n\u201cThe armed forces go to the villages, open fire to disperse the population, and then ransack the houses making off with chickens and goats, which is typical of Frelimo,\u201d he claimed, adding that women had been beaten and houses torched. \n\n\u201cEither Frelimo does not know how to control its troops or there is a clear lack of will,\u201d he said. \n\nAbuses have also been reported to international organisations by Mozambicans who have sought refuge in neighbouring countries. \n\nAuthorities in December said more than 3,000 people fleeing the conflict now live in government camps, while the UN refugee agency says another 8,600 have been forced to cross the border to Malawi and Zimbabwe. \n\nIn spite of the allegations, Dhlakama has no intention of calling off the ceasefire, which he admits he unilaterally proclaimed in a bid to reopen peace negotiations. \n\nThe peace talks with international mediators resumed in May last year but failed to prevent the escalation of tensions and by mid-December the mediators quit the country. \n\n\u201cI must speak to President Nyusi in the coming days because we are still waiting for him to give the signal for the return of mediators,\u201d said Dhlakama. \n\nThe rebel leader said he will leave his mountain base only to sign a peace agreement. \n\n\u201cWe are not going to give up on the truce. But every day someone calls me up to ask me to extend it beyond March 4. And I always tell them that it will depend on the progress of the negotiations.\u201d \n\n© 2017 AFP","author":{"publishingPlatform":{},"name":"Adrien BARBIER"},"topics":[{"name":"Mozambique news","group":"Regional"},{"name":"Africa news","group":"Regional"}],"title":"Mozambique rebel leader accuses soldiers of violating ceasefire","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Africa","subregion":"Southern Africa","countryCode":"ZA","country":"South Africa"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"Roodepoort Record","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"535027901","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"368"},"name":"Roodepoort Record","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Geographic","Global","Standard","News"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://roodepoortrecord.co.za"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695199277132","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:50:23Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

Organisers claim this a record number of the little dogs in the one place at the one time. \n\nMark Ellis, the organiser of Sunday's Werriwa Wiener Dash at the Bungendore Show, believes the turnout of 154 dachshunds for the event constitutes a world record for the number of the sausage dogs in one place at one time.\n\n\"We had miniatures, long hairs, short hairs, standards and wire hairs,\" he said. \"They came from all over; some even travelled from Melbourne.\n\nWhile Mr Ellis wasn't able to engage the attention of the people from Guinness, who ruled the record being sought was too \"specialised\" to interest them, he is happy to claim the record with any other contenders needing to prove him wrong.\n\nAlthough the quirky event, which has captured the imagination of dachshund lovers from across NSW and the ACT, is only in its second year it has already become one of the feature events of the Bungendore Show.\n\nThis year's dash winner was Buddy, owned by Jacqueline Winzenberg of Page in the ACT. Buddy's award was presented by NSW Deputy Premier and local member John Barilaro.\n\nOne hundred and twenty seven dogs turned up for the inaugural event in 2016.\n\nBungendore Show, which was first held in the 1840s, has gone from strength to strength in recent decades, this year's showgirl, Hanna Darmody, 22, said.\n\nMs Darmody, whose family own a Bungendore butchery, said she could recall helping with the catering at the show as a toddler almost 20 years ago.\n\n\"I've seen the event grow as the town has grown,\" she said. \"It is a great bridge between country and city; the showgirl competition is a good way to get young people involved and promotes opportunities in agriculture.\"\n\nShow organisers said this year's event, which enjoyed the best weather conditions in three years, was an unqualified success with more than 2000 people passing through the gates before lunch.\n\nIn addition to the usual attractions in the show ring and the pavilions and the dachshund dash, the 2017 event offered visitors a chance to get a close look at the Anzac Centennial 18 pounder gun.\n\nThe World War I-era weapon, which also saw service during World War II,was restored by the Royal Australian Artillery Company in conjunction with veteran coach builder Jim Frecklington.
