SOUTH AFRICA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"UNITED STATES","domains":["GEO"],"score":"95"},{"name":"SOUTH AFRICA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"93"},{"name":"UNITED STATES; FLORIDA, USA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"79"},{"name":"IRAQ","domains":["GEO"],"score":"69"},{"name":"AFRICA","domains":["GEO"],"score":"90"}],"wordCount":"597","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395988539&p=2kx&v=1&x=nfYd0TkjtYA9JJdq4CaCxA","id":"29395988539","content":"Clay Neely / The Newnan Times-Herald \n \nAfter coming to America in 2004, Suzette and Jan Smit are now American citizens following a Naturalization ceremony on Friday. \n \nThirteen years after arriving in the United States, local pharmacists Jan and Suzette Smit are now American citizens. \n\n \nFriday morning, the family was sworn in as new citizens during a naturalization ceremony in a federal office building in Atlanta. \n \n\u201cFor us, it\u2019s an enormous accomplishment and an honor,\u201d said Jan Smit. \u201cYou don\u2019t realize what a big deal this. It\u2019s so difficult to get into the United States.\u201d \n \nTheir journey from Pretoria, South Africa, to Newnan began in 2004 when Albertsons, a regional grocery store in Florida, began recruiting pharmacists to come to America. The family had spent the previous decade running its own pharmacy in South Africa. \n \nComing to America was something entirely new for the family that had no idea what awaited them. \n \n\u201cYou see America on the television and the movies, but you never really know what it\u2019s all about until you come,\u201d Jan Smit said. \u201cBut the people down here in the South are so warm and friendly \u2013 they welcomed us from the moment we arrived, and it really made it easy for us to get established.\u201d \n \nJan Smit eventually went to work for Rite Aid while Suzette worked for Jet Logistics in Atlanta. In 2008, their youngest son joined the Army and was deployed to Iraq for several tours before returning home. \n \nIn 2011, he sponsored his parents for a green card, and two years later, the family opened Health Mart Pharmacy on Baker Road. \n \nLocated directly across the street from the Health Mart is a CVS Pharmacy. This wasn\u2019t an oversight, but intentional, according to Jan Smit. \n \n\u201cWhen I was an apprentice in South Africa, a pharmacist once told me to open your store across the street from a very busy pharmacy,\u201d Jan Smit recalled. \u201cYou\u2019ll ultimately get not only the runoff, but also those who don\u2019t really care for that style of operation.\u201d \n \nSuzette Smit agreed, citing there are two different kinds of pharmacies \u2013 the big box, express, drive-thru kind and the smaller, family operated kind where customers become friends. \n \n\u201cWe only get the nice people in here,\u201d Suzette Smit joked. \u201cWhen it\u2019s a family-run business, it inevitably becomes an extension of your home, and that\u2019s how you interact with every person who comes through your door.\u201d \n \nJodi Morril is a regular customer who attests to the Smit family philosophy when it comes to business. \n \n\u201cThey take a simple visit to the pharmacy and turn it into a neighborly visit,\u201d she said. \u201cIn a world where big businesses rush you through the checkout line, this wonderful couple and especially, Miss Suzette, engage you in conversation, make lengthy calls to the insurance provider if there are any problems, and make you feel as if you\u2019ve gone to a neighbor's home for a visit.\u201d \n \nRunning the pharmacy is a full-time operation, but when the Smit family gets home, they spend their time connecting with family from across the globe. While their youngest son is a registered nurse at Tanner Hospital in Carrollton, their other two children are in New Zealand and South Africa. \n \nTheir Sundays are spent at church and then on Skype where they visit with their two grandchildren. Suzette Smit is the author of two novels and joined the Coweta Writers Group where she has immersed herself in the local writing scene. \n \n\u201cBecoming a citizen is a tremendous honor,\u201d Jan Smit said. \u201cWe\u2019re extremely proud to have achieved this accomplishment and to call Newnan home.\u201d \n \n**** \n \nClay Neely: clay@newnan.com, @clayneely","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Society news","group":"Society"},{"name":"South Africa news","group":"Regional"}],"title":"Smit family celebrates new citizenship","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Coweta","zipCode":"30263","state":"Georgia","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Newnan","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"The Times-Herald","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"192729622","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"349"},"name":"The Times-Herald","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Geographic","Local","News","Standard"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.times-herald.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695199669688","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:53:25Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}
{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T07:53:25Z","duplicateGroupId":"29395988542","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"LEGISLATIVE BODIES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"77"},{"name":"BUSINESS EXPANSION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"66"},{"name":"ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGE INDUSTRY","domains":["IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"BEER & ALE WHOLESALERS","domains":["IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"RETAILERS","domains":["IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"WHOLESALERS","domains":["IND"],"score":"89"},{"name":"BEER & ALE","domains":["IND"],"score":"91"},{"name":"LEGISLATION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"90"},{"name":"ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES","domains":["IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"BREWERIES","domains":["IND"],"score":"91"},{"name":"US STATE GOVERNMENT","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"BEER, WINE & LIQUOR STORES","domains":["IND"],"score":"78"},{"name":"TOUR PACKAGES","domains":["IND"],"score":"70"},{"name":"DIRECT SALES FORCE","domains":["SUB"],"score":"78"},{"name":"BEVERAGE SALES & REVENUES","domains":["IND"],"score":"78"}],"wordCount":"670","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395988542&p=2kx&v=1&x=1oj0OUEt7R535WOwDl9NsA","id":"29395988542","content":"Maggie Bowers / The Newnan Times-Herald \n \nAbide Brewery co-owner Evan Scanlan, pours beer for guests attending Saturday\u2019s \u201cGeorgia Beer Day\u201d celebration. \n \nTwo years after the \u201cGeorgia Beer Jobs Bill\u201d gave craft breweries in the state the opportunity to kind of, sort of, in a roundabout way, sell some beer to customers, a new bill introduced in the Georgia General Assembly may allow breweries to actually sell moderate amounts of beer directly to customers.  \n\n \nSenate Bill 85, introduced Friday, is billed as a compromise between the state\u2019s brewers and wholesalers. Georgia has a strict three-tier system that separates producers, wholesalers and retailers.  \n \nUnder the bill, Georgia\u2019s small breweries could offer direct sales by the glass on premises, and even sell up to a case \u2013 or case equivalent \u2013 worth of beer \u201cto go\u201d to individuals. Breweries would be limited to direct-selling 3,000 barrels of beer per year. \n \nBreweries in the state, including Newnan\u2019s Abide Brewing, are hoping that the bill will pass. \n \nRight now, Abide doesn\u2019t bottle its beer, but the brewery is in the midst of a major expansion. \u201cIf the bill goes through, we will be pushing pretty hard to get into a package form,\u201d said Evan Scanlan, one of the brewery\u2019s three owners.  \n \nUnder the current scenario, breweries can sell tours \u2013 and give away servings of beer. With a standard tour, visitors get a souvenir glass and 36 ounces of beer, divided into six, six-ounce pours. State law allows tour packages to also include some to-go beer, in a sealed \u201cgrowler\u201d bottle, but Abide doesn\u2019t offer that.  \n \nAccording to co-owner Philip Leonard, the biggest advantage of the bill passing would be a greater potential for sales. It would allow Abide Brewery to sell directly to consumers, and would lift the mandate for all events to follow the pattern of the standard tour.  \n \n\u201cRight now, we sell something, then the distributor sells it, then the retailer,\u201d Leonard explained. \u201cThe passing of the law may allow us to recapture some of the profit.\u201d This would, in turn, allow Abide to expand the business.  \n \nLeonard added that the owners may even be able to host events at the brewery in which they could sell directly to the customers. Birthday parties, corporate retreats or meetings could be hosted at the brewery without the current restrictions.  \n \nThe brewery has 13 beers on tap, Scanlan said. There are five beers currently on the market and available in local restaurants. The other eight spots are filled by various new brews. \u201cWe do a bunch of test batching, to see what the public likes. They kind of have input of what might be coming out next or what people are liking the most.\u201d  \n \nAbide may brew just one barrel of a test brew, and never make it again. \n \nThe bill was introduced the day before \u201cGeorgia Beer Day,\u201d which was Saturday. Breweries all over the state, including Abide, held events and are working to advocate for passage of SB 85.  \n \nIn 2015, the \u201cBeer Jobs Bill\u201d originally allowed direct sales, but by the time it passed, it was considerably pared down. In the summer and fall of 2016, representatives from breweries and wholesalers met to work out a compromise, according to Travis Peterman of the Georgia Craft Brewers Guild.  \n \nSB 85 was introduced by Sen. Rick Jeffares, R-McDonough, chairman of the Senate Regulated Industries and Utilities Committee. \n \n\u201cWith suggestions championed by both brewers and wholesalers, Lt. Governor Casey Cagle, Speaker of the House David Ralston, R-Blue Ridge, House Regulated Industries Committee Chairman Howard Maxwell, R-Dallas, and Senator Jeffares have provided guidance to create this legislation. Their commitment to supporting the small businesses of Georgia shines through in SB 85,\u201d said Nancy Palmer, Executive Director of the Georgia Craft Brewers Guild. Palmer said the business leaders of Georgia Beer Wholesalers Association were also crucial in the process.  \n \nBeing able to have direct sales will make breweries more of an attraction or destination, and bring in tourism, Scanlan said. That\u2019s what\u2019s happening in North Carolina and other states. Scanlan said that breweries in North Carolina have seen tremendous growth. ","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Beverages industry news","group":"Industry"}],"title":"New bill may allow some direct beer sales from breweries","source":{"category":"Local","location":{"region":"Americas","subregion":"Northern America","county":"Coweta","zipCode":"30263","state":"Georgia","countryCode":"US","zipArea":"Newnan","country":"United States"},"editorialRank":"4","name":"The Times-Herald","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"192729622","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"349"},"name":"The Times-Herald","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Geographic","Local","News","Standard"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://www.times-herald.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695199669982","language":"English","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:53:25Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}
{"tags":[],"publishingPlatform":{},"estimatedPublishedDate":"2017-01-29T02:30:00Z","duplicateGroupId":"29394677058","companies":[],"licenses":[{"name":"Publicly Available"}],"indexTerms":[{"name":"LEGISLATION","domains":["SUB"],"score":"89"},{"name":"POLICE FORCES","domains":["SUB"],"score":"50"},{"name":"FEMINISM & WOMEN'S RIGHTS","domains":["SUB"],"score":"72"}],"wordCount":"1133","url":"http://ct.moreover.com/?a=29395988732&p=2kx&v=1&x=IPs9tVaLFmHKOf60ox0w0A","id":"29395988732","content":"In recent days the Government has announced that it will legislate on sexual consent. Under the proposed new law, a person is incapable of agreeing to sex if they are asleep, unconscious or unlawfully detained; if they can't communicate owing to a physical disability; or if only a third person gives permission on their behalf. In recent days the Government has announced that it will legislate on sexual consent. Under the proposed new law, a person is incapable of agreeing to sex if they are asleep, unconscious or unlawfully detained; if they can't communicate owing to a physical disability; or if only a third person gives permission on their behalf. But the next circumstance - that a person is unable to consent to sex if they are intoxicated - should give pause for thought.\n\nFirst, let's be clear: rape is abhorrent and perpetrators should be dealt with using the full force of the law. But the recent rise of new-wave radical feminism - on university campuses and social media - is troubling, in particular, when it comes to sexual consent.\n\nMany within this movement insist that, when having sex, 'no means no' and 'yes means yes' and two civilised people would never stray outside those bounds. Originally created by UK police forces but largely circulated by the modern-day feminist movement, it explains how asking for sex should be treated in the exact same way as asking someone if they would like a cuppa. If you ask a person: \"Do you want a cup of tea?\" and they say \"Yes please, I would LOVE it\" then you know they want tea. \n\nBut if they say: \"No thank you\" then don't make them tea. At all. In the real world, there is rarely a moment where one person asks: \"Do you want to have sex?\" and the other responds with a definitive \"yes\". \n\nHow many people reading this article have long relied on non-verbal cues during sexual encounters? A smile, a certain look, time spent kissing with hands slowly moving lower, is usually enough to let intimacy unfold naturally. A woman saying: \"Yes! I want to have sex with you\" - especially on the first night - isn't part of the age-old art of seduction.\n\nAnd, whether we like it or not, we live in a world where women don't like to appear as though they pursue sex. They want to be desired by men, to feel they are being slowly seduced. Don't agree? Then ask yourself why more women don't carry condoms. For further evidence of female desire, just look at extreme examples of men leading the way in romantic literature. It is swamped with politically incorrect sexual fantasies of a woman being forcefully 'taken'.\n\nEverywhere from Ayn Rand's Fountainhead - when the macho architect Howard Roark first takes his love interest, the author describes how \"She fought like an animal but she made no sound... He had thrown her down on the bed... his hands moving all over her body... It could be the act of a lover or the act of a soldier violating an enemy woman\" (she promptly falls madly in love with him) - to Tom Wolfe's A Man in Full where a woman describes her very first night with her husband of 30 years. \n\nShe explains: \"Charlie practically raped her... [yet] she had a visceral memory of the most intense ecstasy of her life. It was so taboo even to intimate that you could be aroused by male physical power that she never said a word about it to anyone.\" Even modern-day movies such as Fifty Shades of Grey are awash with fantasies of just that: grey sexual encounters. There's a reason the sequel will be packed out with giggling women when it opens in theatres next month, just in time for St Valentine's Day.\n\nAlthough I am not saying women would ever want their 'forced' fantasies to happen in real life - unless it is a man they feel safe with and are sexually attracted to - what I am saying is that it points to women's complex underlying attitudes towards sex.\n\nWomen want to feel they can enjoy sex often without feeling they are leading the way. In real life, they can have a breathless or coy approach when agreeing to sex. It is rarely: \"Yes, let's do it.\" So try being a man initiating sex in that context. And that's even before we add alcohol into the mix. Then it becomes a minefield.\n\nSex is a delicate enough area that needs your full attention - especially the first time - to stop miscommunication and to ensure everyone is fully aware and happy with what is happening. Alcohol dramatically hinders this process.\n\nThis is even more pertinent when you consider how we are among the world's biggest drinkers and our dating scene largely revolves around alcohol. It used to be the case that men drank twice to 12 times the amount of the average woman but - partly as a result of the feminist movement - women now drink just as much as men. The Ladette culture that has prevailed since the 1990s has given rise to 'keeping up with the boys' and women are putting their safety at risk.\n\nAs a progressive society, men's binge drinking should have been tackled rather than allowing women to play 'catch up' and call it 'equality'.\n\nThese days we are not even allowed to challenge the rise of the female drinking culture for fear of being labelled - at best sexist - or, worse still, a rape apologist. So instead we change the law - in a way that protects women and puts the onus on men. In light of this law and our failure to tackle the issue of our binge drinking culture, women can now drink as much as they want, while men are expected to stay largely sober and on guard for fear they misread sexual signals. Is that realistic or even fair? \n\nWhat happens if a woman initially seems to be a willing participant in a sexual encounter but can't remember it the following day? But what if the guy is drunk too and also has vague, patchy memories of the night before she regrets it and cries foul?\n\nAs part of a radio documentary on sexual consent for my final year thesis I've sat with men who have experienced this kind of situation. They were shaken, confused and ashen-faced to think that someone could even consider them a rapist following a blurry encounter. \n\nThe idea that 'rape is rape' fails to take into account that physical force is very different to two people who misunderstand a situation - especially when intoxicated. Just don't be surprised if a case comes to court in the coming years and we are all forced to take a long hard look at sexual consent -in all its shades of She denied her sister bidding for her first title in Melbourne to add to her Grand Slam haul of seven. \n \nBoth sisters will go home with a total of $5.6million Australian dollars, with Serena winning $3.7million. \n \n\n \nWilliams, 35, had equalled Stefanie Graf\u2019s record with her 2016 Wimbledon triumph. The German\u2019s original 22-slam mark had stood since the 1999 French Open. \n \nSerena now has seven Australian Open titles, making it her joint-most successful Grand Slam alongside Wimbledon. She has also won six US Open titles and four at Roland Garros. \n \nThe sisters were facing off in the 28th match of their storied rivalry, and their ninth Grand Slam final, but the first since 2009. \n \nVenus and Serena mowed throughout the draw playing vintage tennis to book their first meeting in Melbourne in 14 years, when Serena took a three-set thriller to capture the first of two Non-Calendar Year \u201cSerena\u201d Slams. \n \n\u201cI don\u2019t think I felt at all awkward,\u201d Venus said in her post-match press conference. \u201cI felt ready. I mean, I haven\u2019t played in a final for a number of years, but I don\u2019t think it\u2019s something you forget. I mean, I played a good amount of \u2019em, so\u2026 \n \nSaturday\u2019s match was similarly tense, with both sisters aware of what was on the line; a win for Serena would not only break the Open Era record but also restore her atop the WTA rankings after dropping to No.2 last summer at the US Open. \n \nVenus and Serena exchanged breaks to start the match, with the No.2 seed settling in sooner to take the opening set behind seven aces and 16 winners. \n \nThe crowd did its best to lift Venus in the second set in the hopes of seeing a decider, and the Americans continued performing at a high level throughout the 81 minute match. \n \n\u201cI feel like I had opportunities, for sure,\u201d Venus said. \u201cJust missed some shots. But it\u2019s not like I missed shots that I wasn\u2019t going for. I went for those shots. It\u2019s a matter of inches. \n \n\u201cSome errors here or there can mean the difference between a break of serve or a hold.\u201d \n \nBut Serena, who came into the match with a 20-0 record after winning the first set in Grand Slam finals, proved too strong in the end, breaking serve just once in the seventh game to serve out the record-breaking victory, hitting a total of 27 winners to just 23 unforced. \n \nSerena improved her overall head-to-head against Venus to 17-11, and an impressive 7-2 in Grand Slam finals \u2013 the only two losses to big sister coming at the 2001 US Open and 2008 Wimbledon Championships, which was, incidentally, the last time the Williams sisters and Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal all met in the same major final. \n \nThe win was Serena\u2019s 316th at Grand Slam tournaments, improving on her already-record total, and returns her to No.1 in the world, usurping Angelique Kerber. \n \nAs for Venus, the result is still her best at a major tournament in seven years, and brings her back to within 200 points of returning to the top 10. \n \nIn the meantime, she was more than happy to give kudos to her younger sister after her historic achievement. \n \n\u201c[23], it\u2019s a great number,\u201d Venus said. \u201cI know she would like to have a little more. Who wouldn\u2019t? It was a great moment. I\u2019m very happy that she\u2019s been able to, you know, get to No.23 because there\u2019s 22 ahead of that that she also earned, and she earned it. \n \n\u201cIt was great to have an opportunity to play for the title. That\u2019s exactly where I want to be standing during these Grand Slams, is on finals day, having an opportunity. That\u2019s the highlight of all this, is to be in that moment.\u201d \n \n\u201cThere\u2019s no way I would be here at 23 without her,\u201d Serena Williams said of her sister. \u201cThere\u2019s no way I would be at one without her. She\u2019s the only reason that I\u2019m standing here today. She\u2019s the only reason that the Williams sisters exist.\u201d \n  Share this","author":{"publishingPlatform":{}},"topics":[{"name":"Sports: latest","group":"Sports"},{"name":"Sports: tennis news","group":"Sports"}],"title":"Serena Williams beats Venus to set slam record","source":{"category":"National","location":{"region":"Africa","subregion":"Western Africa","countryCode":"NG","country":"Nigeria"},"editorialRank":"3","name":"CitizenNG.com","feed":{"genre":"General","tags":[],"id":"533853821","inWhiteList":"true","rank":{"inboundLinkCount":"9"},"name":"CitizenNG.com","dataFormat":"text","autoTopics":[],"language":"Unassigned","editorialTopics":["Consumer","Sports"],"mediaType":"News"},"homeUrl":"http://thecitizenng.com"},"dataFormat":"text","outboundUrls":[],"sequenceId":"695199672667","language":"English","publishedDate":"2017-01-29T04:35:46Z","adultLanguage":"false","harvestDate":"2017-01-29T07:53:28Z","media":{"logo":[],"audio":[],"images":[],"video":[]}}

A dawn raid by US drones and helicopters Sunday killed three Yemeni tribal chiefs allegedly linked to Al-Qaeda as well as a number of civilians, tribal and local sources said. \n\nAir-to-surface missiles and helicopter machinegun fire were also used in the attack on houses in Yakla district, in the central province of Baida, the sources said. \n\nBrothers Abdulraouf and Sultan al-Zahab and Saif Alawai al-Jawfi were killed in the strikes carried out by drones and Apache helicopters, they said. \n\n\"There are casualties among the civilians that were in the targeted houses,\" said one source. \n\nThe tribal chiefs were known to be linked to Al-Qaeda, the sources said. \n\nThe Zahab brothers have two other Al-Qaeda brothers who were also killed in the past by drone strikes. \n\nThe United States, which considers the extremist group's Yemen-based franchise, Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula, to be its most dangerous, is the only force operating drones over Yemen. \n\nBut it only sporadically reports on a long-running bombing campaign against AQAP. \n\nOn January 14, the Pentagon announced the killing a senior Al-Qaeda operative in Baida a week earlier in an air strike. \n\nAl-Qaeda and the Islamic State jihadist group have exploited a power vacuum created by the two-year-old conflict in Yemen between the government and Shiite Huthi rebels, especially in the
